{{disambig-two|the [[Men|Mannish]] King of [[Luthany]]|High King of the Elves|[[Ingwë]]}} {{infobox character | people=[[Men|Man]] | name=Ing | image= | caption= | pronun= | othernames=''Ingwë'' | titles=King of Luthany | position= | location=[[Luthany]]
''possibly'' [[Tol Eressëa]] | affiliation= | language= | birth= | birthlocation= | rule= | death= | deathlocation= | age= | notablefor= | house= | parentage=Unknown (descendant of [[Ermon]])According to another text, he was the descendant of ''both'' Ermon and [[Elmir]], the first two [[Men]] to awaken at [[Murmenalda]]. | siblings= | spouse= | children=Unknown (ancestor of [[Ælfwine]]) | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Ing''' or '''Ingwë'''This is not to be confused with the character of [[Ingwë]], King of the [[Vanyar]] in the later legendarium, nor with that of Inwë his literary predecessor. While there may be some connection between these two characters, they are ''not'' one and the same.{{LT2|VI}}, pp. 304-5 was the [[Men|Mannish]] King of [[Luthany]], and the legendary ancestor of the [[wikipedia:Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxons]],{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''24''', p. 306 according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''15''', p. 301 == History == Following the march of the [[Elves]] of [[Kôr]] to the [[Great Lands]] to free the enslaved [[Gnomes]], the remaining Elves waged a war with evil Men, and afterwards retreated to the land of [[Luthany]] ruled by Ing, who was friendly to them.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''18''', pp. 302-3 After some time, [[Eärendel]], fleeing from [[Ossë]], came to Luthany and was given aid by Ing. In return for his help, Eärendel allowed Ing to drink ''[[limpë]]'', which made him immortal.{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''23''', p. 306In another outline, it was the Elves living in Luthany who gave Ing ''limpë'', with Eärendel coming to Luthany after the invasion of the [[Rúmhoth]] has already taken place. Eärendel also spoke to him of [[Tol Eressëa]], where many of the Elves of Luthany moved to. This inspired Ing, "longing for the Elves", to try to sail there; however, due to the anger of Ossë for helping Eärendel, he and all his fleet were driven east, and only Ing managed to survive. There, he became the king of the people known as the [[Ingwaiwar]] (named after him). He instructed them in many things, including the [[Valar]] and the Elves, and set their hearts toward sailing west. At some point, Ing left the Ingwaiwar, departing in a boat, and was never heard of again.In another note, he went to, and reached Tol Eressëa. There, it is said that one day he would [[Faring Forth|lead the Elves of Tol Eressëa back to Luthany]].{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''22''', pp. 305-6 His people, the Ingwaiwar, eventually conquered Luthany and became known as the [[wikipedia:English people|English]]. However, unlike all other previous invaders, they were friendly to the Elves owing to the teachings of Ing.{{LT2|VI}}, outlines '''20''' and '''21''', p. 304 Among Ing's descendants was [[Ælfwine]] the Mariner, who travelled to Tol Eressëa, and learned the histories of the Elves.{{LT2|VI}}, p. 309 == Etymology == The name ''Ing'' is of unknown origin. Another name for the character was ''Ingwë''. ''Ing'' was also an earlier, rejected ([[Qenya]]) name for the character of [[Inwë]], the leader of the [[Vanyar|Teleri]] in ''The Book of Lost Tales''.{{LT1|In}}, p. 22 In the ''[[Sketch of the Mythology]]'', from c. [[1926]], the name ''Ing'' is described as being the Gnomish form of ''[[Ingwë]]'', as opposed to the earlier conception of ''Ing'' being a rejected Qenya form of ''Inwë''.{{SM|2a}}, p. 44 == Genealogy == {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | ERM |ERM=[[Ermon]]}} {{familytree | |:| }} {{familytree | |:| }} {{familytree | ING |ING='''ING'''}} {{familytree | |:| |}} {{familytree | |:| |}} {{familytree | AEL |AEL=[[Ælfwine]]}} {{familytree/end}} == Inspiration == The main inspiration behind the character was the figure of ''[[Wikipedia:Yngvi|Ing]]'' in the ''[[wikipedia:Old English rune poem|Runic Poem]]'', of whom it is said: "Ing was first seen by men among the [[wikipedia:Geats|East Danes]], until he departed eastwards over the waves; his car sped after him." The [[Ingwaiwar]], his followers, were probably based on the people called the ''[[wikipedia:Ingaevones|Inguaeones]]'', the ancestors of the English. {{references|notes}} [[Category:Characters in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Gnomish names]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Qenya names]] [[Category:Rulers in the Great Lands]]
